Worst-Case Scenario - Regulated Toxic Chemicals

The worst-case scenario selected is a storage tank rupture that release the entire tank contents of 150,000 pounds of Methyl Chloride.  Methyl Chloride is used to produce methyl based quaternary ammonium compounds at the facility.  This is the only storage tank for Methyl Chloride and the release is contained within a concrete dike.  This area is equipped with a deluge system and fire fighting equipment.  Potential public receptors include Village of Mapleton residents, Hollis Park District employees and patrons, Ingredion employees, Evonik employees, Chemtura employees, Caterpillar Inc. employees, Air Liquide employees, and the general public and commerce within the affected radius.  The estimated distance to the toxic end point (0.82 mg/l) is 3.2 miles according to EPA's RMP*Comp model.



Worst-Case Scenario - Regulated Flammable Chemicals

The worst-case scenario selected is a storage tank rupture that releases the entire contents of 231,000 pounds of anhydrous Dimethylamine (DMA).  DMA is used in the production of amine products at the facility.  This is the largest storage tank of Dimethylamine and the release is contained within a concrete dike.  This area is equipped with a deluge system and fire fighting equipment.  Potential public receptors include Village of Mapleton residents, Hollis Park District employees and patrons, Ingredion employees, Evonik employees, Chemtura employees, Caterpillar Inc. employees, Air Liquide employees, and the general public and commerce within the affected radius.  Assuming the released DMA results in a vapor cloud explosion, the estimated distiance to 1 psi overpressure is 0.50 miles according to EPA's RMP*Comp model.  



Alternate Case Release Scenario - Regulated Toxic Chemicals

Alternate case scenarios were conducted for each regulated toxic chemical.  The individual scenarios are identi

fied as follows:



Phosphorous Trichloride (PCl3)

The alternate case scenario selected is a 0.5 inch diameter rupture in a rail car unloading hose that releases 9,370 pounds of PCl3.  The release is contained within a concrete dike sump.  This area is equipped with fire fighting equipment.  Active mitigation is employed.  Potential public receptors include Village of Mapleton residents, Hollis Park District employees and patrons, Evonik employees, Chemtura employees, Caterpillar Inc. employees, Air Liquide employees, and the general public and commerce within the affected radius.  The estimated distance to the toxic end point (0.028 mg/l) is 0.40 miles according to EPA's RMP*Comp model, and the estimated duration of the release to the atmosphere is 40 minutes.



Methyl Chloride (MeCl)

The alternate case scenario selected is a 0.5 inch diameter rupture in a rail car unloading hose that releases 5,000 pounds of MeCl.  The release is contained within a concrete sump.  This area is equipped with fire fighting equipment.  Potential public receptors include Village of Mapleton residents, Hollis Park District employees and patrons, Evonik employees, Chemtura employees, Caterpillar Inc. employees, Air Liquided employees, and the general public and commerce within the affected radius.  The estimated distance to the toxic end point (0.082mg/l) is 0.20 miles according to EPA's RMP*Comp model, and the estimated duration of the release to the atmosphere is 20 minutes.  





Alternate Case Release Scenario - Regulated Flammable Chemicals

The alternate case secnario selected is a 0.5 inch diameter rupture in a 2 inch storage tank transfer line that releases 5,000 pounds of anhydrous Dimethylamine (DMA).  Potential public receptors include Village of Mapleton residents, Hollis Park District employees and patrons, Evonik employees, Chemtura Corporation employees, Caterpillar Inc. employees, Air Liquide employees, and the general public and commerce within the affected radius.

Assuming the released DMA results in a vapor cloud explosion, the estimated distance to 1 psi overpressure is 0.08 miles according to EPA's RMP*Comp model.  



We are using this alternate case release scenario information to help us ensure that our emergency response plan and the community emergency plan address all reasonable contingency cases.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Lonza Inc. complies with OSHA"s PSM rule and EPA's RMP rule.  We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key feature of successful prevention programs including:

  - Process Safety Information

  - Process Hazard Analysis

  - Training

  - Mechanical Integrity

  - Management of Change

  - Pre-Startup Reviews

  - Compliance Audits

  - Incident Investigation

  - Employee Participation

  - Hot Work Permits

  - Contractor Safety

  - Site Security



These individual elements of our prevention program all work together to assist our efforts to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our facility management and our employees are committed to safe work procedures defined by the prevention program.  We have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.



Five Year Accident History

We keep records for all significant accidential chemical releases that occur at our facility.  During the past five (5) years, we have not experienced an accidental release from covered processes that has resulted in either deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site or known deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelterings-in-place, property damage or environmental damage off site.



Emergency Response Program

Our emergency response program covers various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  We have written procedures and pre-plans

and we conduct training for initial incident response, emergency responder contact, regulatory agency and community notifications, maintenance of emergency response equipment, and specific response management.  Furthermore, we actively participate in our Peoria County Emergency Management Agency (EMA) coordinating our plan with the Peoria County EMA community emergency response plan.



We have a trained emergency response team on site, and we coordinate with Timber Hollis Fire Department for handling larger emergency incidents.  Our emergency response team has incident command, fire, rescue, and Hazmat training and has conducted joint training and drills with the Peoria County EMA and neighboring industries.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Lonza subscribes to the Society of Chemical Manufacturers & Affiliates (SOCMA) "ChemStewards" initiative, which provides for continuous improvements in all aspects of our safety, health, and environmental programs.  In addition, plant safety programs include behavior based safety awareness training, a near miss program, safety awareness sessions, department safety meetings and celebrations of safety milestone achievements.
